titleStmt.title: The discontented colonell writtten by Sir Iohn Sucklin.
titleStmt.author: Suckling, John, Sir, 1609-1642.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by E. G. for Francis Eagles-field ...,

note.p: Republished with alterations in 1646 in his "Fragmenta aurea" under title: Brennoralt.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

div.p: THE DISCONTENTED COLONELL. Written by Sir IOHN SUCKLIN.
LONDON, Printed by E. G. for Francis Eagles-field, and are to be sold at the Marrigold in Pauls Church-yard.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item:
Miessa.
Melidor.
A Lord . Counsellours to the King.

Villanor.
Granivert.
Marrinell . Cavaliers and Officers Vnder Brennoralt.
Palatine of Menser, Governour, one of the chiefe Rebells.
Orillia, a waiting woman to Francelia.
Raguelin, a servant in the governours House, but spy to Brennoralt.

div.head: Actus primus.
Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I Say the Court is but a narrow circuit,
Though something elevate about the common;
A kind of Ants nest in the great wilde field,
Orecharg'd with multitudes of quick inhabitants,
Who still are miserably busied, get in,
What the loose foot of prodigality,
As fast doth throw abroad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good.
A most eternall place of low affronts,
And then as low submissions.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Right.
High cowards in Revenges 'mongst themselves,
And onely valiant, when they mischiefe others,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Stars, that would have no name,
But for the ills they threaten in conjunction:

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: A race of shallow, and unskillfull Pilots,
Which doe misguide the ship, even in the calm,
And in great stormes, serve but as weight
To sinke it,
More, prithee more.
Tis musique to my melancholy.
My Lord; a cloud of dust and men
The sentinells from the East gate discover,
And as they guesse, the storme bends this way.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let it be.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let it be,
I will not fight to day,
Bid Strathman draw to the Trenches,
On, prithee on.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The King employes a company of formall Leards,
Men who have no other other proofe of their
Long life, but that they are old.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Right, and if they'r wise,
Tis for themselves, not others,
As old men ever are.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Colonell, Colonell,
The enemy's at hand, kills all the Centries,
Yong Alermin leads them on agen.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let him lead them off agen then,

sp.speaker: Second Sol.
sp.l: Colonell.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Be gone,
If th'a afraid, goe hide thy selfe,

sp.speaker: Second Sol.
sp.l: What a devill ayles hee?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: This Almerin's the ague of the Campe,
He shakes it once a day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is the ill conscience rather,
He never lets it rest,
Would I were at home agen,
S'foot we lye here ith' trenches, as if it were
For a wind to carry us in the other
World, every houre we expect,
I'le no more on't;

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Prithee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: What man, the worst is but faire death.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And what will that amount to?
Faire Epitaph, a fine account,
Ile home I sweare:

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Arme, arme, my Lord,
And shew your selfe, all's lost else.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: The Rebells, like an unruly flood,
Roule o're the Trenches, and throw downe
All before them.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Wee cannot make a stand.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: He would out-rivall us in honour too
As well as love, but that he must not doe;
Helpe me Stratheman; (puts on Armour,
The danger now growes worthy of our swords,
And O Doran, would heaven there were
No other storme, then this worst Tempest here.

div.stage: Enter Marrinell throwing downe one he carries.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There:
The Sun's the nearest surgeon I know,
And the honestest, if thou recoverest, why so?
If not, the cure's paid; they have mauld us.

div.stage: Enter Granivert with another upon his back.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: A curse light on this powder,
It spoiles valour er'e t'is halfe way it's journey,
What a disadvantage fight we upon in this age?
He that did well heretofore,
Had the broad faire day to shew it in,
Witnesses enough; we must beleeve one another,
'Tis night when we begin.
Smalke, by this hand I can beare with you
No longer, how now? dead as I live;
Stolne away just as he used to a wench,
Well goe thy wayes for a quiet drinker and dyer,
I shall never know thy fellow; (searches his pockets.
These trifles too about thee.
There was never an honester poore wretch
Borne, I thinks, hum Marrinell (she spies Marrinell,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Tis I, Hem. how goes matters?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Scurvily enough;
Yet since our Colonell came, they've got no ground
Of us, a weake Sculler against wind and Tide,
Would have done as much, harke,
This way the Torrent beares.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The villaines all have left us.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Would they had left their feares,
Behind them with the enemy,
But come, since we must.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Hoe Stratheman,
Skirt on the left hand with the horse;
And get betwixt these and that body:
They'r rallied up for rescue.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They'r ours.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Charge through.

div.stage: A shout within. Enter Brennoralt, Stratheman, Doran, Marrinell.

sp.speaker: Bren,
sp.l: What shout is that?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: They've taken Almerin my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Almerin, the devill thanke them for't,
When I had hunted hard all day,
And now at length unhearded the proud deare,
The curs have snatch't him up, sound a retreat.
Ther's nothing now behind; who saw Doran?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Shal we bring Almerin in my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No, Gazing is low Triumph,
Convey him fairely to the King,
Hee fought it fairely.

sp.speaker: Doran.
sp.l: What youth was that whom you bestrid my Lord,
And sav'd from all our Swords to day,
Was he not of the enemy?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: The Governors sonne Fresolin his mistresses brother in Dorancare.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No matter whom.
Pity the rough hand of war, should earely
Courages destroy, before they bud,
Or shew themselves i'th heate of action.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I threw my Lord a youth upon a banke
Which seeking after the retreat I found
Dead, and a Woman the pretty daughter
Of the Forrester, Lucillia.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: See, see, Doran, a sad experiment,
Woman's the cowardliest and coldest thing
The world brings forth,
Yet love as fire workes water,
Makes it boile over, and doe things contrary
To its proper nature,
I should shed a teare could I tell how:
Poore Lucillia, thou didst for me what did
As ill become thee, see her gently buried:
Boy, send the surgeon to the tent; I bleed:
What lowsy cottages they'ave given our soules?
Each petty storme shakes them into disorder,
And costs more paine to patch them up againe
Then they are worth by much:
I'me weary of the tenement.

div.stage: Enter Villanor, Granivert, Marrinell and Stratheman.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Villanor, welcome, welcome, when cam'st thou?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Look, I weare the Kings high way still on my bootes

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A pretty riding phrase, and how, and how, Ladies cheape.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Faith reasonable.
Those toyes were never deare thou know'st;
A little time and industry they'l cost.
But in good faith, not much, some few there are,
That set themselves at mighty rates.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Which we o'th wise passe by,
As things are valued in the market;
I'st not so?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You have said Sir.
Your friend the Rivall's married,
Has obtain'd the long lov'd Lady,
And is such an asse after.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: Hum. Tis ever so,
sp.p: The motions of married people are as of other naturall violent Gentlemen to the place and calme in it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We know this so, and yet we must be fooling.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Faith, women are the baggage of life,
They are troublesome, and hinder us
In the great March; and yet we cannot be without 'em:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You speake very well, and Souldier-like.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: What thou art a wit too I warrant
In our absence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hum. No, no, a poore pretender,
A Candidate, or so, 'gainst the next Sessions,
Wit enough to laugh at you here.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Like enough, valour's a crime,
The wise have still approach't unto the valiant,
And the fooles too.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Raylery apart Granivert,
What accommodation shall we find here?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Cleane straw sweet heart, and meat,
When thou canst get it.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Hum-straw.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Yes.
That's all will be betwixt Incest,
You and your mother Earth must lye together

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Prithee let's be serious, will this last?
How goes affaires?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Well;

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: But well:

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Faith 'tis now upon the turning of the ballance,
A most equall businesse t'wixt Rebellion and Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: What do'st meane?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Why which shall be the vertue, and which shall be the vice?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: How the devill can that be?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O successe is a rare point, hides all the uglinesse!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Prithee what's the quarrell?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Nay, for that excuse us,
Ask the children of peace,
They have the leasure to study it:
We know nothing of it, Liberty they say:

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: S'foot Let the King make an act,
That any man may be unmarried agen;
Ther's liberty for them, a race of
Halfe witted fellowes quarrell about freedome,
And all that while allow the bonds of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: You speake very well Sir;

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Soft, the King and Councell.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Looke, they follow after like tir'd spanniells,
Quest sometimes for company, that is, concurre,
And that's their businesse.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are as weary of this sport,
As a young unthrift of his land.
Any bargaine to be rid on't.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Can you blame them, who's that?

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: Brennoralt, our brave Colonell,
A discontent, but what of that, who is not?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: His face speakes him one,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Th'art in the right!
He lookes still as if he were saying to
Fortune, huswife, goe about your businesse,
Come let's retire to Burrutheus Tent,
Taste a bottle, and speake bold truths,
That's our way now.

sp.speaker: Mies.
sp.l: Thinke not of pardon Sir,
Rigour and mercy us'd in states
Incertainly and in ill times,
Looke not like the effects of vertue,
But necessity, nor will they thanke
Your goodnesse, but your feares.

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: My Lord Revenge in Princes
Should be still imperfect, it is the handsomest,
The King comes to reduce, not ruine.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Who puts but on the face of punishing,
And onely gently acts, but prunes Rebellion,
He makes that flourish, which hee would destroy
Who would not be a rebell? when the hopes
Are vast, the feares but small.

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: I would not, nor you my L. nor any here,
Feare keepes low spirits in, the brave
Doe get above it, when they doe resolve,
Such punishments in infancy of war,
Makes men more desperate, not more yeelding:
The common people are a kind of flies,
Are catcht with honey, not with wormewood,
Severity exasperates the stird up humour,
And state distempers turnes into diseases.

sp.speaker: Brex.
sp.l: The Gods defend great Poland state should bee
Such, as it dares not to take right Physick,
Quarters to rebells Sir.
When you give that to them,
Give that to me which they deserve,
I would not live to see it.

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.l: Turne o're your owne
And other Chronicles, & you shall find (great)
That nothing makes a civill war long liv'd, (Sir
But ransome returning back the brands,
Which unextinct kindled still fiercer fires.

sp.speaker: Mies.
sp.l: Mercy bestowed on those dispute with Swords,
Does loose the Angell face it has,
And is not mercy Sir, but policy,
With a weake vizard on.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Y'have not my thoughts, My Lords,
Nor will it need larger debates to morrow,
In the sight of the besiiged, the rebell dyes,
Miessa, tis your care the mercy
Of high heaven may be offended so,
That it cannot forgive mortalls, much more
Which is not infinite, My Lords.

div.stage: Enter Iphigene, Almerin, as in prison.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: O Almerin,
Would we had never knowne the ruffle of the world,
But were againe by golden banks in solitude,
Where thou and I, sheapherd, and sheapherdesse,
So oft by turnes, as often still have wisht,
That we as easily could have chang'd our Sex,
As Cloths, but all those innocent joyes,
Like glorious morning are retir'd into
Darke sullen clouds, before we know
To value what we had.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Fame, and victory are light huswives.
That throw themselves into the armes,
Not of the valiant, but the fortunate,
To be taken thus:

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Almerin.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Nipt in the bud of honour.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Foild, and by the man,
That doth pretend unto Francelia.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What is't you doe my Almerin?
Sit still and quarrell with the winds
Because there is a shipwrack towards,
And never thinke of saving of the Barque.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: The Barque, what should we doe with that?
When the rich fraight is lost, my name in armes.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Who knowes what prizes are behind,
If you attend, and wait a second voyage.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Never, never,
There are no second voyages in this,
The wounds of honour doe admit no cure.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Those slight ones which misfortune gives must needs,
Else why should mortalls value it at all?
For who would toile to treasure up a wealth,
Which weake inconstancy did keepe,
Or might dispose of?
O my Lord, what newes?

sp.speaker: Melia.
sp.l: As ill as your owne feares could give you,
The Counsell has decreed him sudden death,
And all the wayes to mercy are blockt up.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: My Iphigine,
This was a misbecomming peece of love,
Women would mannage a disaster better,
Againe thou art unkind;
Thy goodnesse is so great, it makes thee faulty;
For whil'st thou think'st to take the trouble from me
Thou giv'st me more, by giving me thine too.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Alas, I am indeed, a uselesse trifle,
A dull, dull thing, for could I now doe any thing
But grieve and pitty, I might helpe;
My thoughts labour to find a way,
But like to birds in cages,
Though they never rest,
They are but where they did set out at first.

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: My Lord your pardon,
The prisoner must retire,
I have receiv'd an order from the King,
Denies accesse to any.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: He cannot be so great a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I thanke him, nor can he use me ill enough;
I onely grieve that I must dye in debt,
A bankrupt, such thy love has made me;
My dearest Iphigene, farewell,
It is no time for ceremony,
Shew me which way I must,

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Griefe strove with such disorder to get out,
It stopt the passage, sent back my words,
That were already on the place.

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: Stay, there is yet a way.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O speake it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But there is danger in't Iphigene,
To thee high danger.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Fright children in the darke with that,
And let me know it,
Ther's no such thing in nature if Almerin be lost.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Thus then,
You must be taken prisoner too,
And by that exchange save Almerin.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why— studies.
Step in and pray him set his hand
About this distance, his seale too.

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: My Lord, I know not what that is.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Setling of money busines foole betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: If't be no more.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Tell him Iphigene and I desire it:
I'le send by Strathocles his servant
A letter to Morat, thus signed, and sealed,
That shall informe the sudden execution,
Command him as the onely meanes,
To save his life, to sally out this night
Upon the Quarters. and endeavour prisoners,
Name you as most secure, and slightliest guarded,
Best pledge of safety; but charge him
That he kill not any, if't be avoydable,
Lest it should enrage the King yet more
And make his death more certaine.

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: He understands it not,
He sayes, but he hath sent it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But should Morat mistrust now,
Or this miscarry.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Come leave it to me,
Ile take the Pylots part
And reach the port, or perish in the art.

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Sleepe is as nice as woman,
The more I court it, the more it flies me.
Thy elder brother will be kinder yet;
Unsent for death will come to morrow.
Well, what can to morrow doe?
'Twill cure the sence of honour lost;
I and my discontents, shall rest together:
What hurt is there in this?
But death against the will,
Is but a slovingly kind of potion;
And though prescrib'd by Heaven,
It goes against mens stomacks,
So does it at fourescore too, when the soul's
Mew'd up in narrow darknesse,
Neither sees, nor heares,
Pish, tis meere fondnesse in our nature,
A certaine clownish cowardise, that still
Would stay at home, and dares not venter
Into forraigne Countries, the better then
Its owne— ha, what Countries? for we receive
Description of the world from our Divines,
● As blind men take relations of this from us,
My thoughts lead me into the darke,
And there they leave me; Ile no more on't.
He knocks within there; some papers & a light;
Ile write toth' King,
Defie him, and provoke a quick dispatch,
I would not hold this lingring doubtfull state,
So long agen for all that hope can give.
sp.stage: Enter 3. or. 4. of the guard with papers, writing,
sp.l: That Sword doth tempt me strangely
Wer't in my hands, t'were worth the other two
But then the guard, it sleepes
And drinkes, may be to contrive,
If so, that I could not passe,
Why if I fall in't, tis better yet then pageantry,
A Scaffold or spectators, more Souldier like.
sp.stage: one of the guard peepes over his shoulder.
sp.l: Vncivill villaine. read my letter?

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: Not I, not I, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Deny it too,

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: Murder, murder,
Arme, arme.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Ile follow, give the Alarum within,
Tis less suspitious, arme, arme, arme.
The enemy, the enemy.

sp.speaker: Sol,
sp.l: Let them come, Let them come, let them come.

div.stage: Enter Souldiers running o're the stage, one throwing away his armes. Enter Almerin.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I heare fresh noise,
The Camp's in great disorder, where am I now?
'Tis strangely darke, goddesse without eyes
Be thou my guide, for blindnesse, and sight,
Are equall sence, and equall use this night.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Trouble not thy selfe, child of discontent,
Twill take no hurt I warrant thee,
The state is but a little drunke,
And when't has spewd up that, that made it so,
Twill be well agen, ther's my opinion in short.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Th'art in the right,
The state's a prety forehanded state,
And will doe reason hereafter,
Let's drinke, and talke no more on't.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A good motion, a good motion, lets drinke.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I, I, lets drinke.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Come, to a mistris.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Agreed, name, name.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Any body, Vermillia.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Away with it.
Shees pretty to walke with,
And witty to talke with,
And pleasant to thinke on,
But the best use of all
Is, her health is a stawle
And helps us, to make us drinke on.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Excellent.
Gentlemen, if you say the word,
Wee'l vant credit, and affect high pleasure,
Shall we?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I, I, Let's doe that.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: What thinke you of the sacrifice now?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Come, wee'l have it,
For trickling teares are vaine.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: The sacrifice, what's that?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Child of ignorance, 'tis a campe health,
An Alamode one, Granivert begin it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Come give it me.
Let me see,
Which of them this Rose will serve, hum, hum, hum,
Bright Star o'the lower Orbe twinkling inviter
Which draw'st (as well as eyes) but sets men righter.
For who at thee begins, comes to the place
Sooner then he, that sets out at the face:
Eyes are seducing lights, that the good women know
And hang out these a nearer way to shew.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fine, and patheticall, come Villanor.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come your liquour, and your stanzons,
Lines, lines.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Of what.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why of any thing your Mistris has given you.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Gentlemen, she never gave me any thing but a box
O'th eare, for offering to kisse her once;

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Of that box then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, I, of that box, of that box.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Since it must be, give me the poyson then
That Box faire Mistris, which thou gav'st me and spits.
Inhumane guesse, is like to cost me three,
Three cups of wine, and verses six,
The Rime will down, but verse for Rime still stickes,
By which you all will easily, Gentles know
I am better drinke then a Po—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: La you there now.
Doran, Doran.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A Hall, a Hall.
To welcome our friend.
Some liquour he
A newer fresh face,
Must not alter our pace,
But make us stil drink the quicker hoe
Wine, Wine
O tis Divine;
Come let us unto our brother.
What's at the tongues end
It forth doth send
And will not a sillable smother.
Then,
It unlockes the brest,
And throwes out the rest,
And learnes us to know each other.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Mad lads, have yee been heere ever since?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Yes faith, thou seest the worst of us.
We debauch in discipline,
Foure and twenty houres is the time,
Burrutheus had the watch to night,
To morrow 'twill be at my tent

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good and dee know what has fallen out to night?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Yes, Granivert and my Lieutenant Colonell,
But they are friends agen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pish, pish, the young Palatine of Florence
And his grave guardian surpris'd to night,
Carried by the enemy out of his quarters.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: As a Chicken by a Kite out of a back-side,
Was't not so?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Yes, my colonell did not love him,
He eates sweet meates upon a march too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Wel, harke ye,
Worse yet, Almerin's gone,
Forc't the Court of Guard where he was prisoner
And has made an escape.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: So pale and frightlesse a wretch,
Drew Priams Curtaine in the dead of night,
And told him, halfe Troy was burn'd,
He was of my mind, I would have done so my self.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Well, there's high suspitions abroad.
Yee shall see strange discovery
I'th counsell of war.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: What counsell speakes?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: One cal'd this morning,
Y'are all sent to.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I'le put on cleane linnen and speake wisely.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: S'foote weele have a round first.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: By all meanes sir.

sp.speaker: Sings.
sp.l: Come let the State stay,
And drinke away,
There is no businsse above it.
It warmes the cold braine,
It makes us speake in high straine,
Hee's a foole that does not approve it.
The Macedon youth
Left behind him this truth,
That nothing is done with much thinking,
He drunke and sought
Till he had what he sought,
The world was his own by good drinking.

div.stage: Enter Generall of the Rebells, Palatine of Trock, Minse, Francelia, Almerin, Norat.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: As your friend my Lord, he has the priviledge of ours,
And may injoy a liberty we would deny
To enemies.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I thanke your Excellence,
O Iphigene he does not know
That thou the nobler part of friendship hold'st,
And do'st oblige whilst I can but acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Opportunity to states men is as the just degree
Of heat to Chymists, it perfects all the worke,
And in this prisoner tis offer'd.
We now are there where men should still begin
To treat upon advantages.
The Palatine of Trock and Minse,
With Almerin shall to the King.
Petition shall be drawne.
Humble in forme, but of that matter
As the bold Macedonian youths would send
To men they did despise for luxury,
The first begets opinion in the world;
Which lookes not far, but on the outside dwells,
To'ther enforces courage in our owne;
For bold demands, must boldly be maintained.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Let al goe on stil in the publique name,
But keepe an eare open to particular offer,
Liberty and publique good
Are like great Oleos,
Must have the upper end stil of our tables,
Tho they are but for shew.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would I had never seene that shape
'Thas poison in't
Yet where dwels good, if il inhabit there?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Presse much Religion,
For tho we dresse the scruples for the multitude,
And for our selves reserve the advantages
(It being much pretext) yet it is necessary
For things of faith are so abstruse and nice
They wil admit dispute continually,
So howsoever other demands appeare,
These never can be prov'd unseasonable
The subject being of so fine a nature,
If not submits himselfe to sense, but scapes
The trials, which concludes al common doubts.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord, you use me, as il painters paint,
Who while they labour to make faces faire,
Neglect to make them like.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Madam, there is no ship-wrack of your
Vertues neare, that you should throw away
Any of al your excellencies
To save the dearest modesty.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: If they proceede with us, we can retreate
Unto expositions, and the peoples votes,
If they refuse us wholly, then we plead
The King's besieged, blockt up so straitly
By some few, that reliefe can find no way
To enter to the King, or yet out to us,
Exclaime against it loud,
Till the Polonians thinke it high injustice,
And with us better yet:
Then easily doe we rise unto our ends,
And wil become their envy through their pitty.
At worst you may confirme our party there,
Encrease it too, there is one Brennoralt
Men call him gallant, but a discontent,
My Cozen, the King has us'd him ill,
Him a hansome whisper will draw,
The afternoone shal perfect
What we have loosely now resolved.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: If in discourse of beauty,
So large an Empire, I doe wander,
It wil become your goodnesse Madam
To set me right;
And in a Country where your selfe is Queene,
Not suffer forrainers to loose themselves,

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: What making revenges Palatine,
And taking prisoners faire Ladies hearts.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Yes my Lord,
And have no better fortune in this war
Then in the other, for while I thinke to take
I am surpris'd my selfe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dissembler, would thou wer't.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: You are a Courtier my Lord,
The Palatine of Ptoceus
Will grace the Hymenealls
And that they may be whilst his stay is heere,
I'le Court my Lord in absence.
Take of you the little strangenesse
Virgins must weare at first.
Looke to the Palatine.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is't my dearest Iphigene.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Not well, I would retire.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: A qualme.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: His colour stole away, sunke downe,
As water in a weather-glasse
Prest by a warme hand.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: A Cordiall of kind looks from the King,
Let us withdraw and heare him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yet to be married?
What? are you mute now?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou cam'st too hastily upon me,
Putst too close the colours to my eye,
I could not see! it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Impossible!
It were impossible it should be otherwise;
What can you imagine there of constancy?
Where 'tis so much their nature to love change,
That when they say, but what they are,
They excuse themselves for what they doe.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: Shee hardly knowes him yet in such an instant.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O you know not how fire flies,
When it doth catch light matter, woman.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No more of that,
Shee's yet the pretiousest thing in al my thoughts,
I if it be so, I am a lost thing in the world, Doran.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Thou wilt in vaine perswade me to be other,
Life which to others is a good that they enjoy,
To me will be an evil I shal suffer.

sp.speaker: Do,
sp.l: Looke on another face, that's present remedy.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: How ill thou do'st conclude,
Cause there are pestilent aires which kill men suddenly
In health; must there be soveraigne
As suddenly to cure in sicknesse?
It never was in nature.
I was a foole to thinke
Death only kept the doores of ill paid Lone,
When or disdaine, or spite
Could let me out as wel.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Right, were I as you
It should trouble me no more
To free my selfe of Love,
Then to spit out that which made me sick.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I'le tell her so, that she may laugh at me,
As at a prisoner threatning his Guard,
He will breake loose, and so is made the Faster,
Shee has charmes Doran,
Can fetch in a rebellious heart,
Even while it is conspiring liberty,
O, she has all the vertues of her sex
And not the vices,
Chast and unsullied,
As first opening Lillies
Or untoucht buds.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Chast, why d'ee honour me
Because I throw my selfe not off a precipice?
Tis her ruine to be otherwise,
Tho we blame those that kil themselves,
We praise not him, that keepes himselfe alive
That deserves nothing.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: And tis the least,
Shee triumphs when she does not appeare:
I have as many rivalls as beholders.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: All that increases but our jealousies,
If you have now such qualmes for that you have not;
What will you have, for that you shal possesse?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Dul Heretique, know I have these
Because I have not her,
When I have her, I shall have these no more:
Her fancy now; Her vertue then wil governe,
And as I watch with doubtfull eye
The wavering needle in the best sundyall
Til it has setled, then the troubles ore,
Because I know when it is fixt, its true,
So heere my doubts are al afore me!
Sure Doran, crown'd conquerours are
But the types of Lovers, which enjoy and really possesse
What tother have in dreams.
I'le send a chalenge to him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Doe and be thought a mad-man,
To what purpose?
If she Love him, she will but hate you more,
Lovers in favour Brennoralt are gamesters,
In good fortune, the more you set them,
The more they get.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Ile see her then this night,
By heaven I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where! in the cittadell.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Know what, and why?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He raves: Brennoralt.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Let me alone,
I conjure thee by the discretion
Left betwixt us; that's thine,
For mine's divorc't by injury of fortune:
Leave me to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Is there such a passage
As thou hast told me of into the Castle?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: There is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: And dar'st thou let me in;

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: If you my Lord dare venture.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: There are no centries neare it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: How to the Chamber afterwards?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Her woman.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Wha't's shee?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: A wicket to my Ladies secrets,
One that stands up to marriage with me.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: There, upon thy life be secret. flings him a purse,

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Else all punishments due to ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Enough:
I am a storme within, till I am there,
O Doran,
That that, which is so pleasant to behold,
Should be such paine within.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Poore Brennoralt;
Thou art still the Martyr of a thousand Tyrants;
Love, honour, and ambition, raigne by turnes,
And shew their power upon thee.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Why let them; I am still Brennoralt,
Even Kings themselves are by their
Servants rul'd sometimes,
Let their owne slaves governe at od houres,
Yet not subject their person or their powers.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Iphigene as in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Iph:
sp.l: WHat have I got by changing place,
But as a wretch which ventures to the warres,
Seeking the misery with paine abroad,
He found, but wisely thought,
And had left at home— weepes,
Fortune thou hast no Tyranny,
Beyond this usage,
Would I had never hop't,
Or had betimes despair'd,
Let never in the gentle theefe,
Or kept him but a guest,
Not made him Lord at all.
Thus as my stormes of griefe,
Carry my teares which should releeve my heart,
Have hurried to the thanklesse Ocean clouds,
And showres which needed not at all the curtesie
When the poore plaines have languisht,
For the want and almost burst asunder,
Ile have this statues place, and undertake,
At my owne charge, to keepe the water full.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: These fond impressions grow too strong upon mee;
They were at first without designe or end
Like the first Elements, that knowes not what,
And why they act, & yet produce strange things,
Poore innocent desires, journeying they know
Not whither, but now they promise to themselves
Strange things, grow insolent, threaten no rest,
Till they be satisfied.
What difference was betweene these Lords?
The one made love as if he by assault,
Would take my heart, so forc't it to defence,
While t'other blew it up with secret mines,
And left no place for it, here he is;
Teares steale too from his eyes,
As if, not daring to be knowne,
To passe that way, make it good cunning griefe;
Thou knew'st thou could'st not dresse thy selfe,
In any other lookes, to make thee lovely.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Francelia, If through the ignorance of places,
I have intruded on your privacies,
Found out forbidden paths,
'Tis fit you pardon Madam.
For 'tis my melancholy, not I offends.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So great a melancholy would well become.
Mischances, such as time cannot repaire,
Those of the warre, are but the petty
Cures, of every comming houre.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Why should I not now tell her all since tis in her,
To save my life, who knowes but she may be
Gallant so farre, as to undoe her selfe,
To make another happy?
Madam, the accidents of warre,
Contribute least to my sad thoughts,
If any such I have;
Imprisonment can never be
Where the place holds what we more love,
And yet,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: In this imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Proceed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I dare not Madam.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I see I do disturbe you, and enter upon your secrets,
Which when I know, I cannot serve you in.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Oh, most of any,
You are the cause of all,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: You Maddam, you alone,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas, that 'tis too, soone to understand,

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Must not you marry Almerin?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: They tell me, 'tis design'd,

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: If he have you, I am for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Lost? the heavens forbid they should designe so ill.
Or when they shall, that I should be the cause.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha, her eyes are strangely kind,
Shee prompts me excellently,
Stars be propitious, and I am safer,
Away: Ile not expect it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: His passion labours for vent.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Is there a hope you will not give your selfe,
To Almerin?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord this ayre is common,
The walkes within are pleasanter.

sp.speaker: Iph
sp.l: Invitation. God of desire be kind,
And fill me now with languages,
Such as thou lend'st thy favorites,
When thou would'st give them easy victory,
And I forgive thee all thy cruelties.

div.stage: Enter Palatine of Trock, Mense. Almerin. Brennoralt, Lords.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Consider too.
That those who are so necessitated to use violence,
Have first beene violent by necessity,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: But still you judge not right of the prerogative,
For oft it stands with power and law,
As with our faith and reason;
It is not still against, that is above my Lord.

sp.speaker: Second Lord.
sp.l: You had of all least reason,
For would the King be unjust he cannot,
Where ther's so little to be had.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Where there is least, there's liberty my Lord;
And 'tis more injury to pull haires
From the bald, then from the bushy heades.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Brennoralt, a word,
My Lord the world has cast i'ts eye upon you,
And mark't you out one of the formost men.
Y'have buried Fame the earliest of any,
And send her still on errands;
Much of the bravery of the Nation,
Has taken up i'ts lodging in you,
And gallant men but coppy from you.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Tis goodly language this; what would it meane?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: The Lithuanians wish you well, and wonder,
So much desert should be so ill rewarded.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: While all the gifts the crowne is master of
Are plac't upon the Empire.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Still I take you not.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then to be plaine,
Our Army would be proud of you,
Pay the neglected scores of merit double,
All that you hold here of command, and what,
Your fortune in this Sigismond has suffer'd,
Repair'd, and make it fairer then it was at first.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: How?
That nothing Lord trifle below ill language,
How came it in thy heart to tempt my honour?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Do'st thinke cause I am angry,
With the King aad state sometimes,
I am fallen out with vertue and my selfe,
Draw, draw or by goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What meanes your Lord-ship?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Draw, I say,
He that would thinke me villaine is one
And I doe weare this toy to purge the world
Of such, they've sav'd thee,
sp.stage: Enter King Lords, Melid. Miessa, they kisse the Kings hand.
sp.l: Wer't thou good natur'd thou wouldst
Love a King the better during life,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If they be just.
They call for gracious answers,
Speedy how ere we promise,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live great 〈◊〉,

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: The 〈◊〉 Sir, are of the wilder sort of creatures,
Must be rid with harsh curbs, and since the warre
Can onely make them tride, what can be us'd but
Swords? where men have falne,
From not respecting Royalty,
Unto a liberty of offending it;
What tho their numbers equalls yours Sir?
And now forc'd by necessity,
Like cuts in narrow roomes,
They fly upon your face:
Thinke you rebellion and loyalty,
Are empty names, and that in subjects hearts,
They give not both and take away the courage;
Shall we beleeve there is no difference,
In good, and bad? no punishment,
Nor no protection? forbid it heaven,
If when great Polands honour, safety too
Hanges in dispute, we should not draw our swords,
Why were we ever taught to weare them Sir?

sp.speaker: Mies,
sp.l: This late commotion in your kingdomes Sir,
Is like a growing wen upon the face,
Which as we cannot looke on without trouble
So tak't away we cannot, without danger,
War there has foulest face, and I
Must feare it, where the pretext is fairest.
Religion, and Liberty,
Most specious names,
Which like the bills of subtle Mountebanks,
Fill'd with great promises of Curing all;
Tho by the wise pass'd by unread, as common cousenage,
Yet by th'unknowing multitude,
They'r still admir'd and flockt to.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is there no way to disabuse them?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: A I's now too late,
the vulgar in religion are
Like unknowne lands,
And those that first possesse them, have them.
Then (Sir) consider, justnesse of cause is nothing,
When things is risen to the point they are?
'Tis either not examin'd or beleev'd
Amongst the world.
The better cause the Grecians had of old,
Yet were the Gods themselves divided in it,
And the foule Ravisher found as good protection,
As the much injur'd husband.
Nor are you (Sir) assur'd of all behind you,
For tho your person in the subjects hearts,
Stands highly honour'd and belov'd,
Yet are there certaine Acts of state,
Which men call grievances abroad.
And tho they bore them in the times of peace,
Yet will they now perchance thinke to be free,
And throw them off for Sir
The Common people are much like the Sea,
Which suffers things to fall,
And sink unto the bottome in a calme,
Which in a storme,
Stur'd and enrag'd it lifts, and doth keepe up.
Then time,
Distempers cures, more safely (Sir) then physicke,
Or instant letting blood; Religion now
Is a young mistris there, for which each man will fight
And dye at least; Let it alone a while,
And t'will become a kind of married wife,
People will be content to live with it,
In quietnesse, if that at least may be,
My voyce is therefore (Sir) for peace.

sp.speaker: Mies.
sp.l: Were Sir the question simply warre or peace,
It were no more then shortly to be ask't,
Whether we would be well or ill,
Since war, the sicknesse of a kingdome is,
And peace the Health:
But here I doe conceive,
'Twill rather be, whether we had not better
Endure sharpe sicknesse for a time, t'enjoy
A perfect strength, then have it languish on us;
For peace and war, is an incestuous line,
Have still begot each other;
Those men that highly now have broke all lawes,
(The great one onely tis t'wixt man and man,
What safety can they promise? tho they give it;
Will they not still suspect, and justly too,
That all those bonds should be
Broken agen to them; so being still in feares,
And jealousies themselves, they must infect
The people, for in such a case,
The private safety is a publique trouble,
Nor will they ever want pretext,
Since he that will
Maintaine it with his Sword hee's injur'd,
May say't at any time:
Then (Sir) as terrible as war appeares,
My vote is for't, nor shall I ever care,
How ugly my Physicians shall be,
So he can doe the cure,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In entring Physick,
I thinke Sir none so much considers
The Doctors face, as his owne body,
To keepe on foot the war, with all the wants,
Is to let bloud, and take strong potions,
In dangerous sicknesse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I see a wonder not to find my Lords,
This difference in opinion, the subject's large,
Nor can we there too much dispute, where, when
We erre tis at a kingdomes charge,
Peace and war are in themselues indifferent,
And time doth stampe them, either good or bad,
But here the place, is much considerable,
War in our owne.
Is like to heat within, it makes the body sicke,
When in another country tis but exercise,
Conveyes that heat abroad, and gives it health,
To that I bend my thoughts,
But leave it to our greater counsells,
Which we now assemble:
Meane time exchange of prisoners onely we assent to,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Nothing of Truces Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No:
We will not take up quiet at interest,
Perfect peace or nothing,
Cessations for short times in warre,
Are like small fits of health,
In dangerous sicknesse,
Which while the instant paine seemes to abate,
Flatters us in debauch and worse estate.

div.stage: Enter Iphigene as leading to his chamber, Francelia, Servant with lights. Morat, and another Souldier.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I have not left my selfe a faire retreat,
And must be now either the blest object,
Of your love, or subject of your scorne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I feare some treachery,
And that my eyes have given intelligence;
Unlesse you know there would be weake defence,
You durst not thinke of taking in a heart,
As soone as you sit downe before it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Condemne my love, not of such fond ambition,
It ayms not at a conquest, but Francelia.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They'r very great in this short time.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Tis ever so.
Young and handsome,
Have made acquaintance in nature,
So when they meet, they have the lesse to doe,
It is for age or uglinesse to make aproaches,
Or keepe a distance.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: When I shall see, other perfection,
Which at the best will be but other vanity, not more,
I shall not love it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tis still one step, not to despaire my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Dost thinke he would fight?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Troth it may be not,
Nature in those fine peeces doth as painters.
Hangs out a pleasant excellence
That takes the eye, which is indeed
But a course canvis in the naked truth,
Or some slight stuffe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I have a great mind to tast him.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Fy a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: By this hand, if I thought he courted my
Colonells Mistris in earnest.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
My Lady thinkes the jessamine walkes
Wil be finer, the freshnesse
Of the morning takes off the strength
O'th heate shee says.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Tis well.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Mew, does it so? I suspect vildly,
Wee'l follow him, and see it he be
So far qualified towards a Souldier
As to drinke a— in's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Where are those Keyes?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Harke ye, I dare not doo't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: My Lady wil find.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Scruples.
Are my hopes your feares?
There was no other way I should be any thing
In this lowd world— and now,
S'foot I know she longs to see him too.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Does shee?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Dos't thinke he would desire it else.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I but.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why let me secure it al,
I'le say I found the Keyes, or stole them, come.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Well if you ruine al now,
Here, These enter the garden from the workes,
That the privy walkes, and that the back-stalres,
Then you know my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes I know your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: He comes not,
One wise thought more, and I returne,
I cannot in this art separate the foolish
From the bold so far, but still it tasts
O'th rash.
Why let it tast, it tasts of love too,
And to all actions't gives a pretty relish that.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Oh heere!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: S'foot y'are upon our centries
More on this hand.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Why are there here no guard?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: There needs none,
You presently must passe a place
Whereon's an army in defence,
It is so steepe and strait.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Tis well.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: These are the steps of danger,
Looke to your way my Lord.

div.stage: Francelia as in bed, he draws the Curtaine.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I doe not find such difficulties,
Waite me thereabouts.
So misers looke upon their Gold,
Which while they joy to see, they feare to loose
The pleasure of the sight scarce equalling
The jealousy of being dispossest by others,
Her face is like the milky way ith' Sky,
A meeting of gentle lights without name,
Heavens, shal this fresh ornament of the world
This pretious Lovelinesse,
Passe with other common things
Among the wasts of time?

div.l: What pitty 'twere!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Blesse me,
It is a vision, or Brennoralt.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Brennoralt, Lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Brennoralt, ignorance guard me
What ist y'have done my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Alas, I were but in too good estate,
If I knew what I did.
But why aske you Madam?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It much amazes me to thinke,
How you came hither
And what could bring you too in danger thus,
My honour, and your owne life
Nothing but saving of my brother.
Could make me now preserve you.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Reproach me not, the follies you your selfe
Make me commit,
I am reduc'd to such extremity
That love himselfe, high tyrant as he is,
If he could see, would pitty me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Would Heaven you did, for tis a paine to tel you.
I come to accuse you of injustice Madam,
You first begot my passion,
And was content (at least you seem so)
That it should live,
Yet since never would contribute unto it
Nor look upon it: as if you had desir'd
It's being for no other end,
But for the pleasure of its ruine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why doe you labour that to make me guilty of
An injury to you, which when it is one,
Al mankind is alike engaged,
And must have quarrell to me.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: I have done il, you chide me justly Madam,
I'le lay it not on you, but on my wretched selfe.
For I am taught that Heavenly bodies
Are not malicious in their influence,
But by the disposition of the subject.
They tel me you must marry Almerin,
Sure such excellencie ought to be
The recompence of vertue
Not the sacrifice of parents wisedome,
Should it not Madam?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Twould injure me,
Were it thought otherwise.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: And shal he have you then
That knew you yesterday?
Is there in Martyrdome no juster way
But this, that holds a finger in the fire
A little time? should the Crown from them
That have endur'd the flame with constancie

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If the discovery wil ease your thoughts my Lord,
Know Almerin is the man I never saw.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: You doe not marry then, condemned man
Thus heare, and thus receive reprieves.
One question more, and I am gone.
Is there to Latitude of eternity
A hope for Brennoralt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Have I place at al when you doe think of men?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Lord, a high one,
I must be singular: did I not value you?
The world doth set great rates upon you,
And you have first deserv'd them.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Is this al?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: O be lesse kind or kinder,
Give me more pitty, or more cruelty Francelia,
I cannot live without this, nor dy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I feare my Lord,
You must not hope beyond it.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Not hope?
This is not sure the body to this soule,
It was mistaken shuffled, in through hast:
Why else should that have so much love,
And this want love lines to make that Love
Received— I wil raise honour to a point
It never was,
Doe things of such a victorious greatnesse:
Shee shal love me, she shall.
I wil deserve her, tho I have her not,
Ther's something yet in that.
Madam wilt please you pardon my offence,
Oh fates that I must cal thus my affections.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I wil doe any thing, so you wil think of me
And of your selfe my Lord, and how your stay
Endangers both.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Alas your pardon is more necessary to my selfe
Then life's to me, but I am gone
Blessing such as my wishes for you in
Their extasies could never reach, fal on you,
May every thing contribute to preserve
Your excellence (my destruction)
Great as the torments I have in it.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: WHy so 'tis wel: fortune I thinke thee still,
I dare not cal thee villaine neither,
'Twas plotted from the first:
That's certaine, it lookes that way:
Hum catcht in a trap.
Heer's something yet to trust to,
This was the entry, these the staires,
But whither afterward?
He that is sure to perish on the Land
May quit the nicety of card and compasse,
And safe to his discretion put to Sea,
He shal have my hand to't.

div.stage: Enter Raguelin, Orillia, the waiting Woman.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Looke, by this light tis day.

sp.speaker: Oril.
sp.l: Not by this, by tother 'tis indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Thou art such another peece of temptation.
My Lord raves by this time.
An hundred to one the Centinells wil discover
Us too, then doe I pay for night-watch.

sp.speaker: Oril.
sp.l: Fy upon thee, thou art as feareful as a
Young Colt, boylest at every thing, foole, as
If Lovers considered howers, i'le peepe in.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am as weary of this wench
As if I were married to her,
She hangs upon me like an ape upon a Horse,
Shee's as common too, as a Barbers Glasse,
Conscienst like a Dy-dapper.

sp.speaker: Oril.
sp.l: Raguelin, there is no body within
My Lady sleepes this houre at least.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Good, the Devills even with me,
Not be an honest man neither,
What course now?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Nay sir we shal order you.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Dogs.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What tumult's this? ha Brennoralt,
Tis he in spite of his disguise,
What makes he here?
Hee's lost for ever if he discover'd:
How now companions, why doe you use
My friend thus

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Your friend my Lord, if he be your friend,
H'has us'd us as il,
H'has plaid the devill among us,
Six of our men has Surgeons work this moneth,
We found him climing of the wall.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: He had no word neither,
Nor any Language but a blow.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You wil be doing these wild things my Lord.
Good faith y'are too blame, if y'had desir'd
To view the wals or trenches, 'twas but
Speaking, we are not nice,
I would my selfe had waited on you.
They'r the new out-works you would see perchance,
My Lord, wee'l take the nearer way, and
Privater, here through the sally port.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: What the devill's this sure I dreame?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Nay y'are so officious.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: Death, could I ghesse he was a friend?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: 'Twas ever to be thought so,
How could he come there else?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: Friend, or no friend he might have
Left us something to pay the Surgeon with.
Grant me that, or I'le beat you to him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Brennoralt, start not,
I pay thee back a life I owe thee,
And blesse my stars they gave me power to doe,
The debt lay heavy on me,
A Horse waits you there, a trumpet too
Which you may keepe lest he should prate,
No ceremony, tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou hast astonisht me.
Thy youth has triumpht in one single act
O' eal the age can boast, and J wil stay
To tell thee so, were they now firing
All their Cannons on me,
Farewel gallant Fresolin
And may reward great as thy vertue crowne thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A peace wil come,
And then thou must be gone,
And whither? when you are once got upon the wing,
You wil not stoope to what shal rise
Before ye, fly to some lure
With more temptation garnisht.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Can you have doubts, and I have not my feares?
By this the readiest, & the sweetest oath I sweare,
I cannot so secure my selfe of you,
But in my absence, I shall be in paine,
I have cast up what it will be to stand
The Governours anger, and which is more hard,
The love of Almerin.
I hold thee now, but by thy owne free grant,
A slight security; alas it may fall out
Giving thy selfe, not knowing thine owne worth,
Or want of mine, thou may'st like one deceiv'd
Resume the gift on better knowledge back.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If I so easily change, I was
Not worth your love,
And by that losse you'l gaine.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But when y'are irrecoverably gone,
'Twill be slight comfort to perswade my selfe
You had a fault, when all that fault must be,
But want of love to me, and that agen,
Find in my much defect, so much excuse,
That it will have no worse name
Then indiscretion, if I inconcern'd doe
Cast it up.— I must have more assurance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have too much already,
And sure my Lord, you wonder while I blush
At such a growth in young perfections.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Why should I wonder Madam?
Love that from two brests sucks,
Must of a child quickly.
Dunces in love stay at the Alphabet,
The inspir'd know all before,
And doe begin still higher.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Madam, Almerin return'd has sent to kisse
Your hand; I told him you were busy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Must I my Lord be busy?
I may be civill, tho not kind,
Tell him I waite him in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: May I not kisse your hands this night?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The world is full of jealous eyes my Lord,
And were they all lock't up, you are a spy,
Once entred in my chamber at strange houres.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The vertue of Francelia is too safe,
To need this little art of preservation,
Thus to divide our selves, is to distract our selves,
A Cherubin dispatches not on earth.
The affaires of heaven, with greater innocence,
Then I will visit; tis but to take a leave
I beg.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: When you are going my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Pish, thou liest, thou liest.
I know he playes with womankind,
Not loves it, thou art impertinent.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Tis the Campe talke my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: The camp's an asse; let me heare no more on't.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: And shall we have peace?
I am no sooner, but the state's so too.
If't be, they will a truce for a moneth onely;
I long to refresh my eyes by this hand,
They have beene so tyr'd, with looking upon faces,
Of this Country.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: And shall not the Donnazella,
To whom we doe wish well a,
Looke babies agen in our eyes.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: Ah, a spritely girle about fifteene,
That melts, when man but takes her by the hand,
Eyes full and quick, with breath
Sweet as double VIolets,
And wholesome as dying straw-berries,
Thick silken eyebrowes high upon the forehead,
And cheekes mingled with pale streakes of red,
Such as the blushing morning never wore.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: O my chops, my chops:

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: With narrow mouth, small teeth,
And lips swelling as if she powted.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: Haire colour'd and curling like buds of
Part tyed in negligence,
Part loosely flowing.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Tyrant, tyrant, tyrant.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: In pinke colour taffata petty-coat,
Lac't smock sleeves dangling,
This vision stolne from her owne bed,
And rustling in ones chamber.

sp.speaker: Vlll.
sp.l: Oh good Granivert, good Granivert.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: With a wax Candle in her hand.
Looking as if she had lost her way,
At twelve at night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh, any houre, any houre.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.l: Now I thinke on't by this hand,
Ile marry, and be long liv'd.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Long liv'd, how?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Oh he that has a wife, eates with an appetite,
Has a very good stomack to't first,
This living at large is destructive,
Variety is like rare sawces,
Provokes too far, and drawes on surfets,
Then the other.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So, Is this a time to foole in?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Draw out your choice men, and away to
Your Colonell immediatly, there's worke
Towards my boyes, there's worke.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Ar't in earnest.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: By this light.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: There's something in that yet.

div.l: This Moity were
Twilight.
Neither night nor day,
Pox upon it.
A storme is worth a thousand
Of your Balme,
There's more variety in it.
div.stage: Enter Almerin, Francelia, as talking earnestly.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Madam, that showes the greatnesse of my passion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The Imperfections rather,
Iealousi's no better signe of love
My Lord, then feavers are of life;
These shew there is a being,
Tho impair'd and perishing,
And that affection but sick and in disorder.
I like it not? Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: So short, and sowre.
The change is visible.

sp.speaker: Iphi.
sp.l: Deare Almerin Welcome,
You have beene absent long.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Not very long.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: To me it has appear'd so.
What say's our campe, am I not blamed there?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: They wonder.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Whil'st we smile.
How have you found the King inclining?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Well; the treaty is not broken, now holds it.
Things are where they were,
thas a kind of face of peace.
You my Lord may when you please returne.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I, Almerin.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, Ile give you an escape.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: 'Tis least to my desires.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Hum:

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Such prisons are beyond all liberty.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Seemes it strange to you?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: No, not at all?
What, you find the Ladies kind?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Civill—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: You make love well too, they say my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Passe my time.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Addresse unto Francelia.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Visit her.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: D'ee know 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Dee know she is my mistris?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I have beene told so.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And doe you court her then?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Why; If I saw the enemy first,
Would you not charge?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: He does allow it too, by heaven;
Laughs at me too, Thou filcher of a heart,
False as thy title to Francelia;
Thy friendship with this I doe throw by—

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I see the cunning now of all my love.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Why thou cam'st so tamely kind,
Suffering surprise; draw.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I will not draw, kill me,
And I shall have no trouble in my death,
Knowing 'tis your pleasure,
As I shall have no pleasure in my life,
Knowing 'tis your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Oh poore, I lookt 'for this,
I knew thou wouldst find 'tas easier to doe
A wrong, then justifie it, but.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I will not, first heare me.
If I love you not, more then I love her,
If I love her more then for your sake,
Heaven strangely punish me.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Take heed how thou dost play with heaven.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: By all that's just, and faire, and good,
By all that you hold deare, and I hold great,
I never had lascivious thought, or e're
Did action that might call in doubt,
My love to Almerin.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: That tongue can charme me into any thing.
I doe beleeve it, prithee be wiser then,
Give me no farther cause of jealousies,
Hurt not my Honour more, and I am well.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But well: of all our passions,
How came it? nature made the worst,
Foule jealousie her favorite,
And if it be not so,
Why tooke she care that every thing,
Should give the monster nourishment,
And left us nothing to destroy it with?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Prithee no more; thou pleadst it cunningly
I feare I shall be made the guilty,
And need my pardon.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: If you could read my heart, you would:
I will be gone too morrow, if that will satisfie,
Indeed I shall not rest untill my innocence,
Be made as plaine as objects to the sense.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Come, you shall nor goe, Ile thinke upon't no more,
Distrust ruines not friendship,
But builds it fairer then it was before.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No more but ten from every company,
For hands are theeves, and rob the glory,
While they take the share,
How goes the night.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Halfe spent my Lord,
We shall have straight,
The moon's weaker light.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: 'Tis time you call in the Officers;
Friends; If ye were men that must be talk't
Into a courage, I had not chosen you.
Danger with its vizard of before this time,
Y'have look't upon, and have out fac't it too.
We are to doe the trick agen, that's all,
And yet we will not sweare,
For he that shrinkes in such an action;
Is damn'd without the helpe of perjury.

sp.speaker: Doran.
sp.l: if from the virgin tower,
Thou spiest a flame, such as the East wind sends,
Forth about the time the day shall breake,
Tell the King I hold the Castle for him,
Bid him come on with all his force,
And he shall find victory so cheape,
'Twill loose it's value,
If I fall, the world has lost a thing,
It us'd not well, and a thing that car'd not
For that world.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Lead on Colonell,
If we doe not fight like.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: No like,
Wee'l be our selves similitude.
And time shall say, when it would tell
That men did well they fought like us.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.l: WHat made the stop?
One in's falling sicknesse had a fit,
Which choakt the passages, but all's well,
Softly, we are neare the place.
div.stage: Alarum within fight, then Enter Almerin in his night Gowne.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: What noise is here to night?
Something on fire, What hoe,
Send to the Virgin Tower, there is disorder,
Thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: All's lost, all's lost,
The enemy's upon the place of Armes,
And is by this time Master of that
And of the Tower.

sp.speaker: Alm:
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Save your selfe my Lord,
And haste unto the Campe,
Ruine gets in on every side.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: There's something in't when this fellow
Flies.
Ile see what devill raignes.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Looke, the day breakes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You thinke Ile be so kind, as sweare,
It does not now, indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Will you not send me neither,
Your picture when v'are gone?
That when my eye is famisht for a looke,
It may have where to feed,
And to the painted feast invite my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here, take the Virgin bracelet of my haire,
And if like other men thou shalt hereafter,
Throw it with negligence,
'Mongst the Records of the weake female conquest,
Laugh at the kind words, and misticall contrivement.
If such a time shall come,
Know I am sighing then thy absence Iphigene,
And weeping o're thy false, but pleasing Image.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Francelia, Francelia,
Rise, rise and save thy selfe, the enemy,
That doth not know thy worth, may else destroy it.
Ha; mine eyes grow sick.
A plague has through them stolne into my heart,
And I grow dizzy, feet lead me off agen,
Without the knowledge of my body,
I shall act, I know not what else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How came he in?
Deare Iphigene, wee are betraid,
Let's raise the Castle, lest he should returne.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: That were to make all publique,
Feare not, Ile satisfie his anger,
I can doe it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes with some quarrell,
And bring my honour, and my love in danger
Looke he returnes. And wreckes of fury,
Like hurried clouds over the face of heaven,
Before a tempest, in his lookes appeare.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: If they would question
What our rage doth act, and make it sin,
They would not thus provoke men.
I am too tame.
Here I denounce a war to al the world,
And thus begin it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ah me, help, help—

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis too late.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Rather then she shal suffer,
My fond deceits involve th'innocent,
I wil discover al.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Ha, what wil he discover?

sp.speaker: Ip.
sp.l: That which shal make thee curse the blindnes
Of thy rage, I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Al,
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, brave and bold.
Because thy perjury deceiv'd me once
And sav'd thy life, thou thinkst to scape agen,
Imposture thus thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Oh hold, I have enough,
Had I hope of life,
Thou shouldst not have this secret.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: What will it be now?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: My Father having long desir'd
A sonne to heire his great possessions,
And in six births successively deceiv'd,
Made a rash vow, and O rash vowes are punisht,
That if the brethen my mother went with
Prov'd not a male, he ne're would know her more,
Then was unhappy Iphigene brought forth,
And by the womens kindnesse made a boy,
And since so bred,
A cruell pitty as it has falne out,
If now thou findst that which thou thoughtst
A friendship in me, love forget it,
It was my joy and death.—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: For curiosity i'le save thee if I can,
Know the end, if't be but losse of blood,
Brests; by all that's good, a woman.
Iphigene.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I thanke thee,
For I was falne asleepe before I had dispatcht,
Sweetest of al thy Sex, Francelia
Forgive me now, my love unto this man
And feare to lose him, taught me a fatal cunning,
Made me court you, and my owne destruction.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Can it be! O mockery of Heaven,
To let me see what my soule often wish't,
And mak't my punishment,
A punishment that were I old in sins,
Were yet too great.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Would you have lov'd me then?
Pray you say would,
For I like teasty sickmen at their death
Would know no newes but health
From the physition.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Canst thou doubt that?
That hast so often seene me extasi'd
When thou wer't drest like woman,
Unwilling ever to believe thee man.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I have enough.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Heavens.

div.l: What thing shall I appeare unto the world?
Here my ignorance might have some excuse,
But there, I was distract.
None but a man enrag'd with anger
To a savagenesse, would e're have drawn
A sword upon such gentle softnesse,
Be kind, and kill me, one of you:
Kill me, if't be but to preserve my wits,
Dearest Iphigene take thy revenge.
It will not misbecome thy sex at all,
Tis act of pitty, not of cruelty,
To dispatch a miserable man.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And thou wouldst be more miserable yet,
While like a bird made prisoner by it selfe,
Thou beatst thy selfe 'gainst every thing,
And vext, passe by that, which should let thee out.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Is it my fault, or Heavens!
For time while she would play upon me,
Like ill musitians wound me up so high,
That I must crack sooner then move in tune.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Stil you rave, while we
For want of present helpe may perish.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Right, a Surgeon, i'le find one instantly,
The enemies at hand too I had forgot,
Oh what fatality govern'd this night!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: How like an unthrifts case wil mine be now?
For al the wealth he looses,
Shifts but the place, and stil the world
Enjoyes it, so will it you
Sweete Iphigene, tho I possesse you not.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What excellency of nature's this?
Have you so perfectly forgiven already,
As to consider me a losse;
I am in doubt what sex I should
Be happier in: climates of freindship
Are not lesse pleasant, cause they are
Lesse scorching with those of Love;
And under them wee'l Live,
Such pretious links of that shal tye
Our soules together, that the chaines of tother
Shall be grosse fetters to it.

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: I feare I cannot stay the making,
Oh, would you had never undeceiv'd me,
For I had died with pleasure,
Believing I had bin your Martyr now:

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: She lookes pale, Francelia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I cannot stay,
A hasty summons hurries me away
And gives.— no— (dies)

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Shee's gon, shee's gon, life like a dyalls hand
Stole from the faire figure ere it was perceiv'd,
What will become of me?
Too too late y'are come,
You may perswade wild birds that wing the aire
Into a cage, assoone as cal her
Wandring spirits back, Ha these strange faces!
Horrour is in them, if I stay
I shall be taken for the murderer,
Oh in what straits they move,
That wander 'twixt the feares of death, and hopes of Love.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Forbeare upon your lives the place,
There dwells Divinity in it, al else
The Castle holds is lawfull prize
Your valours wages, this I claime as mine,
Guard you the doore.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Colonell, shal you use al the women your self?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Away 'tis unreasonable.
Awake faire Saint, and blesse thy poore idolatour,
Ha, pale, and cold, dead!
The sweetest guest fled, murdred by Heaven,
The purple streames not dry yet.
Some villaine has broke in before me,
Rob'd al my hopes, but I will find him out,
And kick his soule to hell I'le doo't

sp.speaker: Speak. Iph.
sp.l: What should I say?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Speake, or by al.

sp.speaker: Iphi
sp.l: Alas, I doe confesse my selfe the unfortunate cause.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: O doe you so,
Hadst thou been cause of all the plagues
That vex mankind, thou'dst been an innocent
To what thou ar't, thou shalt not think repentance.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O thou wert too sudden, and— Dyes.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Was I so?
The lustfull youth would sure have spoild
Her honour, which finding highly guarded
Rage or feare to be reveald, counsel'd
This villaine, is there no more of them?

div.l: Not Enter,
Yes dog through thee, ha a course laid out
Instead of Iphigene, Francelia dead too,
Where shal I begin to curse?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Here if he were thy friend.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Brennoralt.
A gallant sword could never have come in better time.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I have a good one for thee
If that will serve thy turne.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I long to try it.
That fight doth make me desperate,
Sick of my selfe, and of the world.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Didst value him?
A greater villaine did I never kil.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Kill. Bren. Yes. Alm. Ar 't sure of it?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: May be I doe not wake.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Tha'st taken then a guilt off from me,
Would have weigh'd down my sword,
Weakned me to love resistance,
I should have made no sport,
Hadst thou conceald it,
Know Brennoralt thy Sword is stained in
Excellence, great, as the world can boast.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Ha, ha, how thart abus'd,
Looke there, there lies the excellence
Thou speakst of, murdred by him too,
He did confesse he was the cause.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: O inocence il understood, and much swore us'd,
Shee was alas by accident, but I,
I was the cause indeed.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: I wil believe thee too, and kil thee,
Destroy all causes til I make a stop
In nature.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Brevely then:
The title of a Kingdome is a trifle
To our quarrell, sir know by sad mistake
I kil'd thy Mistris Brennoralt, and thou kil'dst mine.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thine?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yes that Iphigene
Tho showne as man unto the world,
Was woman, excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: I understand no riddles guard thee.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: O could they now looke down,
And see how we two strive,
Which first should give revenge,
They would forgive us something of the crime.
Hold prithee give me leave,
To satisfy a curiosity,
I never kist my Iphigene as woman.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Thou motionst well, nor have I taken leave—
Rising it keepes a sweetnesse yet,
As stills from Roses when the flowers are gone.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: So have two fainting pilgrimes scorch't with heat
Unto some neighbour fountaine steps aside.
Kneele first, then laid their warme lips
To the Nymph, and from her coldnesse
Tooke fresh life agen, as we do now.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Lets on our journey if thou art refresht.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Come, and if there be a place reserved
For hightned spirits better then other,
May that which wearies first of ours have it.

div.stage: Fight a good while. Almerin falls.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: If I weary, laugh at me, that's all.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Brave soules above,
Which will be sure inquisitive
For newes from earth, shall yet no other,
But that th'art brave.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: To preserve some Ladies as we guest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Still gallant.
Brennoralt, thy sword not sheathed yet;
Busy still?

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Revenging Sir,
The foulest murder ever blasted eares,
Committed here by Almerin, and Iphigene,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: False, false.
The first created purity was not.
More innocent then Iphigene.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Lives he agen?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Stay thou much wearyed guest,
Till I have throwne amongst them,
We shall looke black else to posterity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What sayes hee?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Something concerning this he labours to discover.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Know 'twas I, who kild Francelia, I alone.

sp.speaker: Minse.
sp.l: O Barbarous returne of my civilities,
Was it thy hand?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Heare and forgive me Minse.
Entring this morning hastily
With resolution to preserve,
The faire Francelia, I found a theefe,
Stealing the treasure which I thought
Belong'd to me, wilde in my mind,
And ruin'd in my honour in much mistaken rage
I wounded both, then O too late I found.
My errour: found Iphigene a woman,
Acting stolne love, to make my owne safe.
And all my jealousies impossible,
Whilst I runne out to bring them cure.
Francelia dies, and Iphigene found here,
I can no more—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: More strange, and intricate,
Iphigene a woman.

sp.speaker: Melid.
sp.l: With this story I am guiltily acquainted,
The first concealments since her love,
And all the wayes to it I have been trusted with.
But sir my griefe joyn'd with the instant businesse,
Begs a deferment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am amaz'd till I doe heare it out,
But in the meane time.
Lest in these mists. merit should lose it selfe,
Those forfeitures of Trock and Minse,
Brennoralt are thine.

sp.speaker: Bren.
sp.l: Tis princely gift, but Sir it comes too late,
Like Sun-beames on the blasted blossomes,
Your favours fall; you should have given
Me this, when't might have rais'd,
Me in mens thoughts, and made me equall,
To Francelias love; I have no end,
Since shee's not: Back to my private life.
I will returne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This melancholy Iune man cure.
Come take the bodies up, and lead the prisoners on.
Triumph and Funerall must walke together.
Cipresse, and Laurell turn'd make up one chaplet,
For wee have got the day.
But bought it at so deare a rate,
that victory it selfe's unfortunate.
